bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, August 25, 1879

div1.p: Reed has heard no word from Emilie Lawrence Reed regarding a necklace he sent her. He studies Spanish, and will take the medical exam when he returns. He gives news of the post commissary and their acquaintances.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, August 25, 1879
div1.p:
Yesterday, I received
two sweet, but unsatisfactory letters from my
little lovie, or at least one of them left out
some information which I very much de-
-sired to get- What kind of a darling little
woman are you, any how, my lovie? But
I will explain all. In your letter of July
31st you tell me that you have heard from
your necklace, but that it had not arrived-
In your darling letters of Aug. 4th & aug. 10th
you don't say one word about your neck-
lace having arrived, so of course I concluded
that my little darling hadn't got it yet;
and this made me very uneasy lest my lovie
had lost it in the mails, & I well knew
how great her disappointment would be.
This being the case, I went, at once, to the
telegraph office & informed Mr Lucas that
up to Aug. 10th, nothing had been heard
from the necklace and that it was probably
lost, & asked him to please investigate through
the Post Office Department. Lo! & behold, this mor-
ning, when I met Mrs Harrison, she greeted me
with, “Well Doctor, I heard from Mrs. Reed, yes-
-terday, & she is very much pleased with her
necklace-” Of course, lovie, this surprised me
very agreeably, & on looking at the letter, I found
it dated august 10th, the very same day on
which you wrote to your old mantee, and
stranger still, this afternoon, I got a tele-
gram from Mr Lucas, in reply, stating that
you acknowledged its receipt august 2nd
&were much pleased. Now, lovie, dear, after
all this, old mantee almost feels hurt,
that his little wifie should tell others about
her necklace, yet she has neglected to write
him one word about it- I'll really have
to give you a good whipping, my precious
wifie, if you treat me this way again- You
told Mrs. H. that you had sent me a pat-
-tern of the necklace, but as it was not
in the letter of august 2nd or 10th, I guess
my little wifie forgot all about it. I'll
have to excuse you, this time, Emilie, lovie,
but if you do not acknowledge the re-
ceipt of the two checks I have sent you,
I shall certainly think that you have lost
all interest in your poor old Arizona
“hubby-” Now, my darling wifie, as I am
pretty sure that you have forgotten to
say anything about the checks, please, on
receipt of this, sit down & acknowledge them
if you only write a dozen lines- I am
so glad that the necklace came to hand
safely, my darling wifie, and that you consider
it so pretty. I have given myself many
moments of uneasiness about it, during
the past week, and was afraid that if you ever
did get it, that it would not please you;
that is, providing it is the same pattern
as Mr Mills; although I must confess that
on a second & third sight of it, each time
it looks prettier- Now I “finks” I have given
my little wifie a real good scolding for
treating her mantee so, and love her heart,
I guess the truth of the matter is that
she wrote her dear old mantee a letter
which never came, explaining all; and “pec”
she “knowledged the old tecks too” if so,
lovie, dear, all “Ise dot” to say is “Boodigs-”!
Poor, little precious, I “pec” she is sad enough,
even though she has got her present, at
the long time her old mantee must stay in
Arizona, and I shouldn't be much surprised to
see a lovely little woman, with wings, come
sailing over the Rocky mountains with a small
boy strapped to her back, “a la Indian”, & alight
in the centre of the parade. You know you
said, my darling wifie, that if I didn't come till next
spring, that you would fly to old Arizona- Now
lovie, dear, abandon at once all thoughts of
returning to this dreadfully isolated territory-
Doesn't my own little darling remember when
we were accomplishing that tedious, weary,
old journey to Otero that “hubby” asked her
if she could ever be induced to return to
Arizona and that she forcibly replied, “Never”!
Well I guess you would now say, my
lovie, “hardly ever”! But mantee knows how
much happier & more comfortable his precious
wife & son will be at home than here, and
he has made up his mind on the subject,
and now only looks forward to next May, as
the time when he will fold his tents &
steal to his little darling's arms. August
Page 4 -- is about passed & there are only left
4 months to Jan. 1st. Then I shall employ in
diligent study, both of Spanish & of my pro-
-fession, for it is very probable that I
will get my 2nd Examination soon after my
return East, and I don't propose to be caught
napping -- my precious wifie must spend her
time in visiting friends & painting “pretties”, and
playing on the piano! Now, love your heart, I
“finks” you are the sweetest, brightest little
“oomsey” that ever lived! In your letter to Mantee
you said that $40 was no inducement, as all
the $133 was yours -- and that was very true &
very “feetning”; but bless my life, in Mrs. H's.
letter, I find that my little precious is hard
at work, just “pawing the ivories” -- all of which
is just too sweet for anything! Trying to steal
a march on ugly old mantee, as usual, &
caught in the attempt. “Boodigs”! by the
dozen, lovie! Well since you have begun,
& now have such an excellent opportunity,
please, lovie, dear, do persevere & learn to
play something for your old mantee, and he
will give you more than $40, a month, and
you will never have to have any more
little girls & boys; or rather I should say,
“hardly ever”! “Boodigs”, lovie, by the quart!
You perceive, my precious wifie, that I am
entirely conversant with “pinafore” and so are
“his sisters & his cousins & his aunts”. By the way,
you never told me what you thought of the
performance you saw in Washington. Did it
come up to your expectations, and make my
prettie lovie shake her “ittle wibs” with laughter?
Won't you have an opportunity of wit-
-nessing theatrical performances in Norfolk
this winter?- I am sorry that Mrs. Vaughan will
go down to the city so early in the Fall; and
think it would be wise for you, my dar-
-ling, to remain at Grand-ma Reed's till
the 1st or Middle of October. But suit Yourself.
Tuesday, aug. 26- As I begin to write, my lovie,
I hear the shrill bark, oft repeated, of a
squirrel chirping away for dear life in
the Cañon abaft the edifice- Don't you re-
member how mantee and old “spin up the
Creek” used to quietly steal down & peep
over the edge of the rocks and catapompher-
-icate the festive squirrel as he pensively
lay on the boulder, dreaming sweet dreams
of Captain Adam's pigeon-box? And how
we used to bring them home & skin them
and eat them for breakfast? Ah! the second
joint of the juicy leg of the squirrel is a
savory morsel to the palate that daily
feeds on bovine flesh! Beef, my dear
wife, still holds its supreme sway at
Fort Apache, unchallenged by the modest
mutton or winsome pork- Indeed, I would
walk all the way to Turkey Creek Hill, to-day,
as hot as it is, to just have the pleasure
of wrapping my tongue about a piece of
nice sugar-cured, juicy ham! The Com-
missary containeth none of the latter, and but
few other things that tempt an appete. Dr
McP. & I were just saying, this morning, that
we would have to haul over our rods & lines
& tempt the wary trout from his summer
lair. Perhaps, Now that Wm, the conqueror,
alias, old “swing on the pivot”, has been re-
-lieved as Quartermaster & Lt. Kingsbury
appointed, perhaps affairs commissarian
& quartermasterian, will be better regula-
-ted- In fact the late 2.M. with the alder-
manic stomach & the blouse too short aft,
was inclined to be too desidiose to be a
very successful Quartermaster. Come, haul down
Page 4 -- is about passed & there are only left
4 months to Jan. 1st. Then I shall employ in
diligent study, both of Spanish & of my pro-
-fession, for it is very probable that I
will get my 2nd Examination soon after my
return East, and I don't propose to be caught
napping -- my precious wifie must spend her
time in visiting friends & painting “pretties”, and
playing on the piano! Now, love your heart, I
“finks” you are the sweetest, brightest little
“oomsey” that ever lived! In your letter to Mantee
you said that $40 was no inducement, as all
the $133 was yours -- and that was very true &
very “feetning” but bless my life, in Mrs. H's.
letter, I find that my little precious is hard
at work, just “pawing the ivories” -- all of which
is just too sweet for anything! Trying to steal
a march on ugly old mantee, as usual, &
caught in the attempt. “Boodigs”! by the
dozen, lovie! Well since you have begun,
& now have such an excellent opportunity,
please, lovie, dear, do persevere & learn to
play something for your old mantee, and he
will give you more than $40, a month, and
you will never have to have any more
little girls & boys; or rather I should say,
“hardly ever”! “Boodigs”, lovie, by the quart!
Page 9. Well, my little lovie, I have never
been so completely knocked down the
“back-stairs”, so to speak, as I was by
the news that you, my precious, were lear-
-ning to dance! “I never did”! or rather “hardly,
ever”! why what can have “awakened” you?
I certainly can't tell, unless it be that you
have, at last, come to the conclusion that dan-
-cing, (especially square dances) is not very dif-
-ficult to learn & is quite useful, at times,
in helping to pass away the time- Although I
am very glad to hear that you are really
“tipping the light fantastic,” yet what surprises
me is that Ma Reed doesn't interfere and break
up your performances- I always did know that
my pretty little wifie could dance, if she would
only try, but mantee never could get you
to skip around with him. And papa's boy
dances too! Love his precious life, papa
is delighted to hear that he continues so
well & is improving so rapidly in talking.
I can hardly bring myself to believe that
he can really talk- Why, he will be such
a big boy by the time that papa comes,
that old “bad daddies” & papa won't know
each other- Give him a hundred kisses every
day for me, my sweet Emilie, & talk to him often
of his absent papa- Let him play with
the pretty apples, mama, but don't let him
eat the green ones- Have you any fruit
this summer, at Harrisonburg, my lovie?
I do hope that you will get a chance
at a plenty of peaches, apples & other
nice fruits -- and of the nice “skip-along”
grapes in Murfreesboro, during the late
fall- You must eat some of those for your
poor old mantee- He thought the little
flower that his little darling sent was
mighty sweet & that it was very loving in
his precious wifie to send it- He had fully
intended to send a nice pretty pink mor-
-ning glory for his little pink of a lovie,
but when he went out, this morning, they had
every one closed & withered- But a pretty one
shall come in his next- The rainy season is
about over, lovie, & the hot sun dries up every thing
very early in the morning- Now, lovie, I have written
10 big pages, which equal 20 small ones, & contain every-
thing I can think about- Mrs. Harrison says she will write
you by the next mail- She & Mrs. H. send very much love-
The latter says she wishes she could be up the Country with you
to learn to paint wooden plates. Best love to Ma, two sister An-
nie, Nita & all- Kisses & love and a hundred “Boodigs”
for both of my little darlings- Love & think of old mantee
a heap- Ever, my precious wife,
div1.closer:
your fond & devoted husband, Walter of
Arizona.
P.S. will
send the check
to Mr Lucas
by this mail
“Boodigs,” lovie,
W.R.
